revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2013}} '''1957 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
{{Year box}}
==[[American football]]== * [[1957 NFL Championship Game|NFL Championship]] – [[1957 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]] won 59-14 over [[1957 Cleveland Browns season|the Cleveland Browns]]. * The [[Auburn Tigers]] are voted national champions by the [[AP Poll]]; don't play in a bowl game on January 1, 1958, due to sanctions
==[[Association football]]== * [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] – [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] beat [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] 2-0.
===England=== * [[Football League First Division|First Division]] – [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] win the [[1956–57 in English football|1956–57]] title. * [[FA Cup]] – [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] beat [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 2-1. * May 15 – [[Stanley Matthews]] makes his last [[England national football team|England]] appearance.
===Other events=== * February 8 – The [[Confederation of African Football]] is founded in [[Khartoum]].
==[[Australian rules football]]== * June 1 – [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] kick a score of 3.30 (48) in wet conditions against [[Swan Districts Football Club|Swan Districts]]’ 5.11 (41). It is the most inaccurate score in senior Australian Rules football history with 27 more behinds than goals.<ref>Atkinson, Graeme and Hanlon, Michael; ''3AW Book of Footy Records: All the Great Players, Matches, Goals, Kicks, Brawls and Sensations from More Than 100 Years of Aussie Rules in Australia''; {{ISBN|1863210091}}</ref> * August 17 – By beating [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] by 21 points, [[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]] secure their first finals position in senior [[Australian Football League|VFL football]], which they joined [[1925 VFL season|in 1925]]. It is the longest finals absence in major Australian sporting history. * August 31 – Hawthorn beat [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] 10.11 (71) to 6.12 (48) in their first senior VFL final. It is the first time Hawthorn had finished above the Blues in their 33 years in the League. * September 7 – [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]] 12.10 (82) draw with [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 13.4 (82) for the first senior WANFL drawn match since June 29, 1946, when the Cardinals drew with [[Swan Districts Football Club|Swan Districts]].<ref name="Draws">[http://waflfootyfacts.net/Teams/All/draws.php WAFL Footy Facts – Draws] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513010548/http://waflfootyfacts.net/Teams/All/draws.php |date=2014-05-13 }}</ref> The 948-game gap between constitutes the longest non-occurrence of draws in a major Australian Rules competition.<ref>See Newman, Alan; "Drawn Game"; in "Port Club's Pennant Hopes Rise"; from ''[[The West Australian]]'', 9 September 1957, p. 21</ref> * September 21 – [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] 17.14 (116) beat Essendon 7.13 (55) [[1957 VFL Grand Final|in the VFL Grand Final]]. It is their third successive premiership, a feat not equalled until the [[Brisbane Lions]] [[2003 AFL Grand Final|in 2003]]. * September 28 – [[Port Adelaide Magpies Football Club|Port Adelaide]] win their fourth successive [[South Australian National Football League|SANFL premiership]], beating [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 15.15 (105) to 13.16 (94). * October 12 – [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] beat [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 10.18 (78) to 9.8 (62) in [[West Australian Football League|the WANFL Grand Final]] for their eighteenth senior WANFL premiership, though their first since the unbeaten season of 1946.
==[[Bandy]]== * [[1957 Bandy World Championship]] is held in Finland and won by {{Bandy|URS}}.
==[[Baseball]]== * January 5 – [[Jackie Robinson]] retires rather than move across town from the [[Brooklyn Dodgers|Dodgers]] to the [[San Francisco Giants|Giants]], to whom he had been traded in December. * [[Roy Sievers]] lead American league with 42 home runs and 114 RBIs, for the last place [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]]. * [[Cy Young Award]] – [[Warren Spahn]], [[Milwaukee Braves (1953–69)|Milwaukee Braves]] * [[1957 World Series|World Series]] – [[1957 Milwaukee Braves season|Milwaukee Braves]] defeat [[1957 New York Yankees season|the New York Yankees]] four games to three. * May 3 – [[Walter O'Malley]], the owner of the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]], agrees to move the team from [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], New York, to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], California. * August 19- [[Horace Stoneham]] announces that the [[San Francisco Giants|Giants]] are moving from [[New York City|New York]] to [[San Francisco]], California. * October 8 – [[Walter O'Malley]] announces that the [[Dodgers]] are going to move from [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], New York, to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], California. * The [[Winnipeg Goldeyes]] win the [[Northern League (baseball, 1902–71)|Northern League]] championship.
==[[Basketball]]== * [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship]]: ** North Carolina wins 54-53 over Kansas * [[1957 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]]: ** [[1956–57 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]] won 4 games to 3 over [[1956–57 St. Louis Hawks season|the St. Louis Hawks]] * The tenth European basketball championship, [[Eurobasket 1957]], is won by the [[Soviet Union national basketball team|Soviet Union]]. * [[Spain|Spanish]] professional basketball league, [[Liga Espanola de Baloncesto]] (Spain Basketball League), a first game held on March 31.(as predecessor for [[Liga ACB]]){{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Boxing]]== * September 23 – [[Carmen Basilio]] won the World Middleweight Championship by a 15-round decision over [[Sugar Ray Robinson]].
==[[Canadian football]]== * [[Grey Cup]] – [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] won 32-7 over the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]]
==[[Cycling]]== * [[1957 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] won by [[Gastone Nencini]] of Italy * [[1957 Tour de France|Tour de France]] – [[Jacques Anquetil]] of France * [[UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race]] – [[Rik Van Steenbergen]] of Belgium
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[1957 World Figure Skating Championships|World Figure Skating Championships]]: ** Men's champion: [[David Jenkins (figure skater)|David Jenkins]], United States ** Ladies' champion: [[Carol Heiss]], United States ** Pair skating champions: [[Barbara Wagner]] & [[Robert Paul]], Canada ** Ice dancing champions: [[June Markham]] & [[Courtney Jones (figure skater)|Courtney Jones]], Great Britain
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1957 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Doug Ford (golfer)|Doug Ford]] * [[1957 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Dick Mayer]] * [[1957 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Bobby Locke]] * [[1957 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Lionel Hebert]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Dick Mayer]] – $65,835 * [[1957 Ryder Cup|Ryder Cup]] – Britain wins 7½ to 4½ over the United States in team golf. '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Reid Jack]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Hillman Robbins]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Patty Berg]] * [[1957 LPGA Championship|LPGA Championship]] – [[Louise Suggs]] * [[1957 U.S. Women's Open Golf Championship|U.S. Women's Open]] – [[Betsy Rawls]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Patty Berg]] * [[LPGA|LPGA Tour]] money leader – [[Patty Berg]] – $16,272
==[[Harness racing]]== * [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers|United States Pacing Triple Crown races]]: *# [[Cane Pace]] – [[Torpid]] *# [[Little Brown Jug (horse racing)|Little Brown Jug]] – [[Torpid]] *# [[Messenger Stakes]] – [[Meadow Lands (horse)|Meadow Lands]] * [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Trotters|United States Trotting Triple Crown races]]: *# [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] – [[Hickory Smoke]] *# [[Yonkers Trot]] *# [[Kentucky Futurity]] * [[Australian Inter Dominion Harness Racing Championship]]: ** Pacers: [[Radiant Venture]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Linwell]] * [[1957 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Sundew (horse)|Sundew]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Straight Draw]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Lyford Cay]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Oroso (horse)|Oroso]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Ballymoss]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Crepello]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Crepello]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Ballymoss]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# May 4 – [[1957 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Iron Liege]] *# [[1957 Preakness Stakes|Preakness Stakes]] – [[Bold Ruler]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Gallant Man]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[Art Ross Trophy]] as the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s leading scorer during the regular season: [[Gordie Howe]], [[Detroit Red Wings]] * [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] for the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s Most Valuable Player: [[Gordie Howe]], [[Detroit Red Wings]] * [[1957 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]] – [[Montreal Canadiens]] win 4 games to 1 over the [[Boston Bruins]] * [[World Hockey Championship]] ** Men's champion: Sweden defeated the Soviet Union * [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship]] – [[Colorado College]] Tigers defeat [[University of Michigan]] Wolverines 13-6 in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]]
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1957 in motorsport|List of 1957 motorsport champions}}
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1957 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1957 NSWRFL season]] *[[1956–57 Northern Rugby Football League season]] / [[1957–58 Northern Rugby Football League season]] *[[1957 Rugby League World Cup]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * 63rd [[1957 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]]
==[[Snooker]]== * [[World Snooker Championship]] – [[John Pulman]] beats [[Jackie Rea]] 39-34
==[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]== * January 31 – death in a road accident of [[John Marshall (swimmer)|John Marshall]] (26), Australian Olympic freestyle swimmer
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Ashley Cooper (tennis)|Ashley Cooper]] (Australia) defeats [[Neale Fraser]] (Australia) 6–3, 9–11, 6–4, 6–2 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Shirley Fry Irvin]] (USA) defeats [[Althea Gibson]] (USA) 6–3, 6–4 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Lew Hoad]] (Australia) defeats [[Ashley Cooper (tennis)|Ashley Cooper]] (Australia) 6–2, 6–1, 6–2 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Althea Gibson]] (USA) defeats [[Darlene Hard]] (USA) 6–3, 6–2 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – '''Events''' * [[Althea Gibson]] becomes the first black player to win a Wimbledon singles championship '''Davis Cup''' * [[1957 Davis Cup]] – {{davis|AUS}} 3–2 {{davis|USA|1912}} at [[Kooyong Stadium]] (grass) [[Melbourne]], Australia
==[[Multi-sport event]]s== * [[2nd Pan Arab Games|Pan Arab Games]] held in [[Beirut, Lebanon]]
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Ted Williams]], [[Major League Baseball]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Althea Gibson]], [[Tennis]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1951 – 2000}}

{{Year nav topic5|2002|chess}} Events in [[chess]] during the year 2002: * The [[Manhattan Chess Club]] closes. Founded in 1877, it was the second oldest chess club in the United States.

page.title: 2006 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships – Men's individual all-round

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Yury Ryazanov]] (link changed to [[Yuri Ryazanov]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
The '''men's individual all-round''' competition at the [[2006 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] was held in [[Aarhus, Denmark]]. [[Kim Dae-Eun]] of [[South Korea]] withdrew from competition before the final started, but the information did not get in time to [[Eugen Spiridonov]] of [[Germany]], who thus missed the final and only 23 gymnasts took part in the competition. The organizers officially apologized for that to the German Gymnastics Union already during the final. ==Medalists== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- align="center" | width=200 bgcolor=gold|'''Gold'''||width=200 bgcolor=silver|'''Silver'''|| width=200 bgcolor=CC9966|'''Bronze''' |- |[[Yang Wei (gymnast)|Yang Wei]]

revision.text:
The '''2006–07 Bangladeshi cricket season''' featured a [[Test cricket|Test series]] between [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]] and [[India national cricket team|India]].
==Honours== * [[National Cricket League of Bangladesh|National Cricket League]] – [[Dhaka Division cricket team|Dhaka Division]] * [[One-Day Cricket League of Bangladesh|One-Day League]] – [[Dhaka Division cricket team|Dhaka Division]] * Most runs – [[Gazi Salahuddin]] 807 @ 42.47 (HS 165) * Most wickets – [[Shabbir Khan]] 53 @ 28.30 (BB 7–134)
==Test series== India played 2 Test matches and 3 limited overs internationals, winning one Test and two internationals. The remaining Test was drawn and the third international was abandoned due to torrential rain. For information about this tour, see: [[Indian cricket team in Bangladesh in 2007]].
==See also== * [[History of cricket in Bangladesh]]
==Further reading== * [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] 2008
==External sources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090816013519/http://www.banglacricket.com/History/articles.php Miscellaneous articles re Bangladesh cricket] * [http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/bangladesh/content/story/260114.html CricInfo re Bangladesh] * [http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/BDESH.html CricketArchive re tournaments in Bangladesh]
{{Bangladeshi cricket seasons}} {{International cricket tours of Bangladesh}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:2006-07 Bangladeshi cricket season}} [[Category:2006 in Bangladeshi cricket]] [[Category:2007 in Bangladeshi cricket]] [[Category:Bangladeshi cricket seasons from 2000–01]] [[Category:Domestic cricket competitions in 2006–07]]

[[Marina Bay, Singapore|Marina Bay]], [[Singapore]] | Course = Temporary street circuit | Course_km = 5.063 | Course_mi = 3.146 | Distance_laps = 61 | Distance_km = 308.706 | Distance_mi = 191.821 | Weather = | Attendance = 263,000{{cite news|title=2018 Singapore Grand Prix Attendance|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/sport/formula-one/formula-one-263000-fans-at-this-years-singapore-grand-prix-second-highest|work=The Straits Times|publisher=The Straits Times|date=16 September 2018|accessdate=17 September 2018}} | Pole_Driver = [[Lewis Hamilton]] | Pole_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] | Pole_Time = 1:36.015 | Pole_Country = GBR | Fast_Driver = {{nowrap|{{flagicon|DEN}} [[Kevin Magnussen]]}} | Fast_Team = [[Haas F1 Team|Haas]]-[[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] | Fast_Time = 1:41.905 | Fast_Lap = 50 {{smaller|(lap record)}} | First_Driver = [[Lewis Hamilton]] | First_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] | First_Country = GBR | Second_Driver = [[Max Verstappen]] | Second_Team = {{nowrap|[[Red Bull Racing]]-[[TAG Heuer]]}} | Second_Country = NED | Third_Driver = [[Sebastian Vettel]] | Third_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] | Third_Country = GER | Lapchart = {{F1Laps2018|SIN}} }} The '''2018 Singapore Grand Prix''' (officially the '''Formula 1 2018 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix''') was a [[Formula One racing|Formula One motor race]] held on 16 September 2018 at the [[Marina Bay Street Circuit]] in [[Marina Bay, Singapore]]. The race was the fifteenth round of the [[2018 Formula One World Championship]] and marked the nineteenth running of the [[Singapore Grand Prix]] and the eleventh time the race was held at Marina Bay. [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] driver [[Lewis Hamilton]] entered the round with a 30-point lead over [[Sebastian Vettel]] in the Drivers' Championship. In the World Constructors' Championship, Mercedes led [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] by 25 points. Hamilton won the race from pole position to further extend his championship lead, ahead of [[Max Verstappen]] and Vettel. ==Classification== ===Qualifying=== {|class=wikitable style="font-size:85%" !rowspan=2|{{Tooltip|Pos.|Qualifying position}} !rowspan=2|{{Tooltip|Car

revision.text:
[[File:Chess Olympiad 2004 Calvia.gif|right|thumb|Official logo of the Olympiad]] The '''36th [[Chess Olympiad]]''', organized by the [[Fédération Internationale des Échecs]] (FIDE) and comprising an openAlthough commonly referred to as the ''men's division'', this section is open to both male and female players. and a women's tournament, as well as several events designed to promote the game of [[chess]], took place between October 14 and October 31, 2004, in [[Calvià]] on the [[Spain|Spanish]] island of [[Majorca]]. There were 129 teams in the open event and 87 in the women's event. In total, 1204 players were registered (some of whom did not play, though). Both tournament sections were officiated by [[International Arbiter|international arbiter]] [[Ignatius Leong]] ([[Singapore]]). Teams were paired across the 14 rounds of competition according to the [[Swiss system tournament|Swiss system]]. The open division was played over four boards per round, whilst the women's was played over three. In the event of a draw, the tie-break was decided by 1. The [[Buchholz system]]; 2. Match points; 3. The [[Sonneborn-Berger]] system; and 4. The [[Buchholz system|Median Buchholz]] system. The [[time control]] for each game permitted each player 90 minutes for all their moves, with an additional 30 seconds increment for each player after each move, beginning with the first. ==Open event== The open division was contested by 129 teams representing 125 nations. Spain, as hosts, fielded three teams, whilst the ''[[International Braille Chess Association]]'' (IBCA) and the ''International Physically Disabled Chess Association'' (IPCA) each provided one squad. Led by first board [[Vasyl Ivanchuk]], the seventh highest-[[ELO rating|rated]] player at the tournament, who recorded 9½ points over 13 rounds, and second reserve [[Sergey Karjakin]] who, aged just 14 years, won 6 of his 7 games (surrendering a [[draw (chess)|draw]] only to American [[Gregory Kaidanov]]), [[Ukraine]] scored all four possible points in each of their first three matches before "only" defeating Russia 2½-1½ in the fourth round, eventually accumulating a nearly insurmountable three-point lead after the penultimate round. The Ukrainian team nevertheless scored three points against France and claimed their first title, three points ahead of Russia, who had entered the tournament as the top [[seed (sports)|seed]], having brought four of the tournament's nine highest-rated players, and as defending six-time champions. [[Armenia]], one of just four teams to draw a match with Ukraine, paced by second board [[Levon Aronian]], who did not lose in 12 games, and third board [[Rafael Vaganian]], who scored 8½ points in 11 games, lost 1½-2½ to Russia in the eighth round. Ultimately, on the strength of a 3½-½ final round defeat of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], they tied Russia's 36½ points. Armenia were placed after Russia, though, on the [[Buchholz chess rating|Buchholz]] [[tiebreaker|tie-breaker]] system employed by the Olympiad, and finished, as in the [[35th Chess Olympiad|previous Olympiad]], with the [[bronze medal]]s. Hosts [[Spain]], led by [[Alexei Shirov]], just managed to squeeze into the top ten. Notable absentees from the tournament were the no. 1 player in the world, [[Garry Kasparov]], as well as classical World Champion [[Vladimir Kramnik]] and his challenger [[Peter Leko]], who were just finishing their [[Classical World Chess Championship 2004|championship match]] (Kramnik retained his title with a 7-7 tie). FIDE Champion [[Rustam Kasimdzhanov]] was present, however, and led [[Uzbekistan]] to 14th place by going undefeated in his 8 games (+4-0=4). :{| class="wikitable" |+ Open event ! # !! Country !! finish |- | A || 1–25 || {{USA}} || 10 || 4 |- | B || 26–51 || {{SUI}} || 29 || 13 |- | C || 52–77 || {{IRL}} || 54 || 43 |- | D || 78–103 || {{TJK}} || 83 || 61 |- | E || 104–129 || {{JPN}} || 112 || 87 |} ===Individual medals=== * [[Performance rating (chess)|Performance rating]]: {{flagicon|GEO}} [[Baadur Jobava]] 2842 * Board 1: {{flagicon|PLE}} [[Evgenij Ermenkov]] 10½ / 12 = 87.5% * Board 2: {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Mohamed Tissir]] 7½ / 9 = 83.3% * Board 3: {{flagicon|ARM}} [[Rafael Vaganian]] 9½ / 12 = 79.2% * Board 4: {{flagicon|GEO}} [[Baadur Jobava]] 8½ / 10 = 85.0% * 1st reserve: {{flagicon|LTU}} [[Vaidas Sakalauskas]] 6 / 7 = 85.7% * 2nd reserve: {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Sergey Karjakin]] and {{flagicon|LBA|1977}} [[Ibrahim Chahrani]] 6½ / 7 = 92.9% ==Women's results== The women's division was contested by 87 teams representing 84 nations. Spain, as hosts, fielded two teams, whilst the ''[[International Braille Chess Association]]'' (IBCA) and the ''International Physically Disabled Chess Association'' (IPCA) each provided one squad. [[China]], led by first board [[Xie Jun]] (ex-World Champion) and second board [[Xu Yuhua]] (future champion), entered the competition as top [[seed (sports)|seed]] and defending triple champions and quickly took the lead, conceding just two [[draw (chess)|draws]] in their first five matches They then defeated the silver and bronze medallists from the [[35th Chess Olympiad|previous Olympiad]], [[Russia]] and [[Poland]] (each 2-1), in the sixth and eighth rounds, respectively. Eventually they carried a six-point lead into a tenth round match with second placed [[United States]]. [[Susan Polgar]] (another ex-World Champion), who entered the tournament as the second highest-rated player and achieved the best performance rating of all, drew Xie Jun, while [[Irina Krush]] won her second board game against Xu Yuhua. A draw by [[Anna Zatonskih]] against [[Zhao Xue]] gave the Americans a 2-1 win over the Chinese team. In rounds eleven and twelve, China drew [[Hungary]] and lost to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], whilst the US team defeated [[Slovakia]] and then scored a 2½-½ victory over [[Hungary]], drawing within three points of China with two rounds remaining. China, though, defeated sixth-seed [[India]] and 12th-seed [[Slovakia]] in the final two rounds, scoring four points to preserve what was ultimately a three-point win and to clinch the [[Vera Menchik]] Trophy for a fourth consecutive time. Second-seed [[Russia]] were led by [[Nadezhda Kosintseva]], who won top honours on the first reserve board for scoring 10 points in 12 rounds. The Russians were only in eighth place after ten rounds but had advanced to fourth place entering the penultimate round, where they faced [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], who they trailed by half a point. Although first board [[Maya Chiburdanidze]] (ex-World Champion) and second board [[Nana Dzagnidze]], who both scored 8½ points for their team over the event, drew their matches, third board [[Lela Javakhishvili]] lost to Kosintseva, giving the Russian team a half-point lead over Georgia; although Georgia defeated [[Ukraine]] 2½-½ in the final round, Russia managed to secure two points against France, equalling Georgia's total and winning the bronze medals on [[tiebreaker|tie-breaks]]. Newly crowned [[Women's World Chess Championship|World Champion]] [[Antoaneta Stefanova]] disappointed as captain of the [[Bulgaria]]n team, scoring only 5½ points in 11 games. Bulgaria eventually finished in 14th place. :{| class="wikitable" ! # !! Country !! Players !! Average

Where two or more teams are tied, they are ordered by best single finish in either division and then by total number of points scored. The trophy, named after the former women's World Champion (1961–78), was created by FIDE in 1997. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! # ! Team ! Open

Average |- | style="background:gold;"| '''1''' | '''{{RUS}}''' | '''2''' | '''3''' | '''2½''' |- | style="background:silver;"| 2 | {{USA}} | 4 | 2 | 3 |- | style="background:#cc9966;"| 3 | {{ARM}} | 3 | 11 | 7 |} ==Controversies== ===Azmaiparashvili incident=== Prior to the closing ceremony of the Olympiad, FIDE vice president [[Zurab Azmaiparashvili]] was arrested by the local [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] as he attempted to ascend the stage. Security officers, in conjunction with local police, did not permit Azmaiparashvili access to tournament organizers, and a struggle ensued after which Azmaiparashvili, having sustained several injuries, was arrested; he secured his release on [[bail]] for [[Euro|€]]500 after having been held for 40 hours, and the charges against him were later dropped. A [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]n, Azmaiparashvili undertook to inform the presenter of the [[Nona Gaprindashvili]] Trophy that the latter ought more clearly to explain Gaprindashvili's contributions to the game of chess (Gaprindashvili had been [[Women's World Chess Championship|World Champion]] for 17 years), but was barred by security. Azmaiparashvili and FIDE averred that Azmaiparashvili was detained and physically accosted despite his having properly and ''clearly [displayed] his [[Very Important Person (person)|VIP]] credentials'' [https://web.archive.org/web/20041204023615/http://www.fide.com/news.asp?id=584], whilst representatives of the Spanish chess federation ("Federación Española de Ajedrez") and tournament organizers blamed Azmaiparashvili for the incident, saying that he ''without any previous provocation, assaulted [an] agent with a head butt to [the] mouth'' [http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/event/calvia04/azmai.html]. ===Drug testing=== Having been formally recognized by the [[International Olympic Committee]] in 1999, in preparation for prospective inclusion in future iterations of the [[Olympic Games]], FIDE implemented (in 2001) [[doping (sport)|doping]] restrictions consistent with those adopted by the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] (WADA). Two players, [[Shaun Press]] of [[Papua New Guinea]] and [[Bobby Miller (chess)|Bobby Miller]] of [[Bermuda]], refused, for various reasons, to submit urine samples for [[drug test|analysis]].[http://www.doping.nl/media/kb/2656/Miller_Panel.pdf Decision of the FIDE Doping Hearing Panel (Miller)][http://www.doping.nl/media/kb/2655/FIDE%202004_Shaun%20Press_Decision.pdf Decision of the FIDE Doping Hearing Panel (Press)] Both players appeared before the FIDE Doping Hearing panel, which decided to cancel the players' performances (Press had scored 7½ points in 14 games, while Miller had scored 3½ points in 9 games), reducing the final score of Papua New Guinea to 15½ (from 23) and that of Bermuda to 18½ (from 22). ==Associated events== Concomitant to the tournaments were several chess-related events planned by the organizing committee of the Olympiad, some under the auspices of FIDE; the events were known collectively as the ''First Chess Festival Calvià 2004''. Within the festival were held [[simultaneous exhibition]]s, game demonstrations and lectures by top Spanish players, and several secondary tournaments, including one for amateur players, a [[rapid chess]] event for players aged under 16, and one for senior players. Chess classes were introduced into the [[primary school|primary]] and [[secondary school]]s, as well as [[Community centre|senior centers]], in and around Calvià in an effort to promote chess generally, and chess films were screened on the [[beach]]es of Calvià every weeknight during the Olympiad. Chess-oriented art was displayed at an ''International Chess Fair'', with prizes for top works awarded by a jury. ==Notes== {{reflist}} * [http://www.olimpbase.org/2004/2004in.html 36th Chess Olympiad: Calvia 2004] OlimpBase * [http://chess-results.com/tnr1881.aspx?lan=1 Olympiad open division detailed results] * [http://chess-results.com/tnr1881.aspx?lan=1&m=-1 Olympiad women's division detailed results] * [http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/event/calvia04/ ''This Week in Chess'' Olympiad round-by-round summaries] {{Chess Olympiads}} [[Category:Chess Olympiads]] [[Category:Women's Chess Olympiads]] [[Category:Chess in Spain]] [[Category:2004 in chess]] [[Category:2004 in Spanish sport]] [[Category:Calvià]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox football tournament | current = [[2018 Birat Gold Cup]] | logo =[[File:Birat Gold Cup official logo.jpg]] |caption = Birat Gold Cup Logo of 2016 | founded = 2012 |teams = 10 | region = {{flag|Nepal}} | venue = [[Sahid Rangsala]] | current champions = [[Nepal Police Club]] (1st title) | most successful club = [[Himalayan Sherpa Club]]
[[Jhapa XI]]
[[Nepal Police Club]]
[[Sankata Boys Sports Club|Sankata Club]]
(1 title) | website = | broadcasters = Makalu TV }} '''Birat Gold Cup''' (lang.Nepali) '''विराट गोल्डकप''' (previously called the '''Mahendra Gold Cup''') is an annual football tournament held in [[Biratnagar]], the second largest metropolitan city of [[Nepal]]{{Cite web|url=http://worldpopulationreview.com/countries/nepal-population/cities/|title=Population of Cities in Nepal (2018)|website=worldpopulationreview.com|access-date=2018-03-27}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.geonames.org/NP/largest-cities-in-nepal.html|title=Biggest Cities Nepal|website=www.geonames.org|access-date=2018-03-27}}. It has been held at the [[Sahid Rangsala]] stadium in [[Biratnagar]], [[Morang]], [[Nepal]] every year since 2012 A.D. The event witnesses participation from several national and international teams, and is amongst the most sought after football tournament of the nation. The tournament for the year 2074 [[Vikram Samvat|B.S.]] (2018 A.D.) is scheduled to host day and night matches and would supposedly be the first Nepalese tournament to do so outside [[Kathmandu]] valley. A total of 10 participating teams from across 4 nations ([[Nepal]], [[India]], [[Bangladesh]] and [[Bhutan]]) are scheduled to play for the cup this year. ==History== Birat Gold Cup football tournament began in the initial years as Mahendra Gold Cup.http://www.nepalopedia.com/event/Birat_Gold_Cup_Football_to_begin_on_March_24_2012/479595141253 Mahendra Gold Cup 2004 was held in [[Biratnagar]].https://thehimalayantimes.com/sports/mahendra-gold-cup-from-today/ In 2012, Mahendra Gold Cup was renamed to Birat Gold Cup. ==2015 Birat Gold Cup== 2015 Birat Gold Cup was planned with an estimated budget NRs 7.7 million.http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2015-02-07/something-for-everyone-in-birat-gold-cup.html [[Tribhuwan Army Club]] and [[Jhapa XI]] reached the final of the Tournament.http://kathmandutoday.com/2015/02/79930.html [[Jhapa XI]] defeated [[Tribhuwan Army Club]] 2-1 to clinch the title.https://www.goonlinenews.com/jhapa-xi-celebrates-victory-after-winning-birat-gold-cup/ ==2016 Birat Gold Cup== 2016 Birat Gold Cup was hosted on [[Sahid Rangsala]], [[Biratnagar]] by [[Morang XI|Morang Football Club]].https://thehimalayantimes.com/business/hosts-morang-thru/ In the final match, [[Nepal Police Club]] clinched title victory by defeating [[Jhapa XI]] 1-0 when Bharat Shah scored the only goal of the match.http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2016-02-28/outsiders-npc-claim-title.html Shah found the post wide open when Jhapa XI goalkeeper Binay Shrestha went on to clear the ball in the 87th minute.https://thehimalayantimes.com/sports/npc-lift-title/ Suman Subedi of Nepal Police Club was adjudged Player of the Tournament. == 2018 Birat Gold Cup == The 2018 Birat Gold Cup is scheduled for March 31 - April 09{{Cite news|url=https://www.nagariknews.com/news/41045/|title=सर्वाधिक राशिको विराट गोल्डकप|last=बस्नेत|first=चुमन|work=Nagarik News|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en}}. The 10 participating teams are{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/biratgoldcup2074/photos/a.1021200628031795.1073741827.1020178141467377/1026724260812765/?type=3&theater|title=Birat Gold Cup 2074|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}: # Thimpu Football Club, Bhutan # Nepal Army Club, Kathmandu # Mohammedan Sporting Club, Kolkata # Sashatra Prahari Bal Team, Kathmandu # Bangladesh Sporting Club, Bangladesh # Manang Marsyangdi Club, Kathmandu # Nepal Police Club, Kathmandu # Rumpum Jhapa 11, Jhapa # Three Star Club, Kathmandu # Rijalco Morang 11, Morang The major sponsors of the event in year 2018 are RUMPUM, Noodles & Maruti Cements ==Results== {| class="wikitable" wikitable ' |- ! Title ! Year (B.S) ! Year (A.D) ! Champions ! Runners-up ! Final score |- | [[2012 Birat Gold Cup|I]] | 2069 | 2012 |'''[[Himalayan Sherpa Club]]''' | [[African United Club]] | 1-0 |- | [[2013 Birat Gold Cup|II]] | 2070 | 2013 |'''[[Sankata Boys Sports Club]]''' | [[APF Club]] | 1-0 |- | [[2015 Birat Gold Cup|III]]http://www.goalnepal.com/tournament_details.php?tid=130 | 2071 | 2015 |'''[[Jhapa XI]]''' | [[Nepal Army Club]] | 2-1 |- | [[2016 Birat Gold Cup|IV]]http://www.goalnepal.com/tournament_details.php?tid=147 | 2072 | 2016 |'''[[Nepal Police Club]]''' | [[Jhapa XI]] | 1-0 |- |V |2074 |2018 | | | |} ==Performance== {| class="wikitable" style="" wikitable sortable ' font-size:95% ! {{Infobox athlete | name = Bram Som | image = 20090822 Bram Som.jpg | imagesize = 200px | fullname = Bram Som | nickname = | height = 1.78 m | weight = 67 kg | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|2|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Terborg]], [[Netherlands]] | personalbest = [[400 metres|400m]] - 46.55 (2009)
[[800 metres|800m]] - 1:43.45 (2006)
[[1500 metres|1500m]] - 3:46.08 (2009) | career = 1987-present | medaltemplates = {{MedalEuropeanChampionships}} {{MedalGold|[[2006 European Championships in Athletics|2006 Gothenburg]]|[[2006 European Athletics Championships – Men's 800 metres|800 metres]]}} | updated = 9 September 2009 }} '''Bram Som''' (born 20 February 1980 in [[Terborg]]) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Running|runner]] who specializes in the [[800 metres]]. His personal best time of 1:43.45 minutes, achieved in August 2006 in [[Zürich]], is also the current Dutch National Record. He missed the 2005 season, but returned in 2006 to win the national Dutch championship for the fifth time since 2000. Later that year he won the European championship. Som participated in the [[2000 Summer Olympics]] as well as the [[2004 Summer Olympics]]. In 2000 he was eliminated in the first round as his time of 1:48.58 was not enough to advance. Four years later he would reach the semi finals in which he came fifth with a time of 1:45.52. He is currently a 800m pacemaker, as of the [[2016 Diamond League]].http://monaco.diamondleague.com/en/programme_resultats_monaco_en/#baseFrame {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160716191204/http://monaco.diamondleague.com/en/programme_resultats_monaco_en/ |date=2016-07-16 {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox non Test cricket team | name = Brazil | image = Brazil Cricket Logo.gif | image_size = | caption = | nickname = | association = [[Associação Brasileira de Cricket|Brazilian Cricket Association]] | icc_status = [[ICC members|Associate member]]{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/422449|title=Ireland and Afghanistan ICC newest full members amid wide-ranging governance reform|work=[[International Cricket Council]]|date=22 June 2017|accessdate=1 September 2018}} | icc_member_year = 2017 | icc_region = [[ICC Americas|Americas]] | WCL_division = n/a (regional tournaments) | coach = | captain = | first_match = {{flagicon|Empire of Brazil|1870}} '''Brazil''' v. {{cr-rt|Argentina}}
(1888) | first_fc = | first_la = | first_t20 = | asofdate = 4 September 2015 }} The '''Brazil national cricket team''' represents the country of [[Brazil]] in [[international cricket]]. The team is organised by the [[Associação Brasileira de Cricket|Brazilian Cricket Association]] (''Cricket Brasil''), which became an affiliate member of the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) in 2002 and an [[ICC members|associate member]] in 2017. However, the national side has a history dating back much longer, with its first recorded international match coming against [[Argentina national cricket team|Argentina]] in 1888.[http://www.icc-cricket.com/about/115/icc-members/associate-members/argentina Argentina] – International Cricket Council. Retrieved 4 September 2015. Regular international competition commenced in the 1920s, and resumed in the 1950s after a gap during World War II. Almost all of Brazil's matches have come against other South American sides, although in recent years the team has participated in several [[ICC Americas]] tournaments, which include sides from Central America and North America.[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/2/2317/Other_Matches.html Other matches played by Brazil] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 4 September 2015. At the [[South American Cricket Championship|South American Championships]], which commenced in 1995, Brazil has played in all but one edition, with a best finish of second at the 1997 tournament.[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/Tables/6/South_American_Championships_1997-98.html South American Championships 1997/98] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 4 September 2015. In April 2018, the ICC decided to grant full [[Twenty20 International]] (T20I) status to all its members. Therefore, all [[Twenty20]] matches played between Brazil and other [[List of International Cricket Council members|ICC members]] after 1 January 2019 will be a full T20I.{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/672322|title=All T20 matches between ICC members to get international status|work=[[International Cricket Council]]|date=26 April 2018|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==History== [[Brazil]] became an [[International Cricket Council|ICC]] member in 2002.[http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Countries/42.html Country: Brazil] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 4 September 2015. Its ICC tournament debut came in 2006, when Brazil took part in Division Three of the [[ICC Americas Championship]] in Suriname. Although Brazil lost all three opening games in that tournament, no doubt due to lack of international exposure, its cricket has developed since then. Brazil won the 2009 [[ICC Americas Championship#Division Three|ICC Americas Championship Division Three]], winning all of its matches against [[Belize national cricket team|Belize]], [[Chile national cricket team|Chile]] and [[Peru national cricket team|Peru]]. This victory enabled Brazil to qualify for the 2010 [[ICC Americas Championship]] Division Two. However, Brazil seemingly struggled at this higher level, thus after losing all of their four matches, were relegated to Division Three. At the [[South American Cricket Championship|South American Championship]], Brazil has participated in all but one edition since the tournament began in 1995, with its best finish being second at the 1997 event. ==Tournament history== ===ICC Americas Championship=== * 2000–04: did not participate * 2006: Division Three fourth place * [[2008 ICC Americas Championship|2008]]: Division Three fifth place * [[ICC Americas Championship|2009]]: Division Three won * [[ICC Americas Championship|2010]]: Division Two fifth place ===South American Championship=== * 1995: 4th place * 1997: 2nd place * 1999: group stage * 2000: 3rd place * 2002: 3rd place * 2004: group stage * 2007: 4th place * 2009: 3rd place * 2011: Did not participate * 2013: 3rd place * 2014: 3rd place * 2015: 2nd place * 2016: 4th place * 2017: 3rd place * 2018: 6th place ==Squad== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! Name |- |Ranil Wickramasinghe |-kuldeep tripathi |- |Matt Featherstone |- |Norman Baldwin |- |Daniel Miziara |- |Greigor Caisley |- |Viki Chaudhry |- |Rudy Hartmann |- |Ian Webster |- |Vincent Bastick |-Abubaker warraich |Guilherme Lefévre |- |Henrique Dolabella |- |Sunny Randolph |- |Alexandre Miziara |} ==See also== *[[ICC Americas Championship]] *[[South American Cricket Championship]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/team/66.html Brazil] at [[Cricinfo]] * [http://www.cricketbrasil.org/ Cricket Brasil – Brazilian Cricket Association] {{pt icon}} / {{en icon}} *[https://archive.is/20130414135955/http://www.brasilcricket.org/en/component/content/article/80-development/106-royal-visit www.brasilcricket.org] (archived 2013) {{en icon}} {{National cricket teams}} {{National sports teams of Brazil}} [[Category:National cricket teams]] [[Category:National sports teams of Brazil|Cricket]] [[Category:Brazil in international cricket]] {{Brazil-sport-stub}} {{cricket-team-stub}}

Founded on 20 October 1944,{{cite book|title=An Encyclopedia of Football in Bolivia – 1914 to 1998|last=Vanauskas|first=Laura|publisher=Heart Books – Belgium|date=1999|page=192|work=The Clubs – Club Deportivo Chaco Petrolero, details and references to formation}} it currently plays in [[Bolivian Football Regional Leagues]], holding home games at ''[[Estadio Hernando Siles]]'', with a 42,000-seat capacity. ==History== The club was founded in 1944 as Club Deportivo Chaco Petrolero, and participated in the [[1971 Copa Libertadores|1971]] and [[1972 Copa Libertadores]]. ==Honours== ===National=== *'''[[Copa Simón Bolívar|Copa Simón Bolivar (Primera División)]]''': 1970 ==Performance in CONMEBOL competitions== *'''[[Copa Libertadores]]''': 2 appearances ::1971 – First Round ::1972 – First Round ==External links== {{Empty section|date=September 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano}} [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1944]] [[Category:Football clubs in Bolivia|Deportivo Municipal]] [[Category:Football clubs in La Paz]] [[Category:1944 establishments in Bolivia]] {{bolivia-sport-stub}} {{SouthAm-footyclub-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Rules for the game clock */ see also
revision.text:
{{About|time management in [[gridiron football]]|time management in other sorts|running out the clock}}
In [[gridiron football]], '''clock management''' is the manipulation of a game clock and [[play clock]] to achieve a desired result, typically near the end of a match. It is analogous to [[Running out the clock|"'''running out the clock"''']] (and associated counter-tactics) seen in many sports, and the act of trying to hasten the game's end is often referred to by this term. Clock managements [[American football strategy|strategies]] are a significant part of American football, where an elaborate set of rules dictates when the game clock stops between [[down (American football)|downs]], and when it continues to run.
==In American football== ===Rules for the game clock=== {{See also|Untimed play}} Upon kickoff, the clock is started when a member of the receiving team touches the ball, or, if the member of the receiving team touches the ball in their end zone, carries the ball out of the end zone. The clock is stopped when that player is tackled or goes out of bounds. (The clock never starts if the receiving team downs the ball in their own end zone for a [[touchback]].) The clock is then restarted when the offense snaps the ball for their first play and continues to run unless one of the following occurs, in which case the clock is stopped at the end of the play and restarts at the next snap unless otherwise provided:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://operations.nfl.com/the-rules/2016-nfl-rulebook/|title=2016 NFL Rulebook|date=|website=NFL Football Operations|at=Rule 4, Sections 3 & 4.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-17}}</ref>
*A player carrying the ball goes out of bounds. Unless after the 2-minute warning of the first half or inside the last 5 minutes of the second half/overtime, the clock is restarted when the ball is spotted, unless another condition causes the clock to start at the snap. *A loose ball is out of bounds. The clock is restarted when the ball is spotted, unless another condition causes the clock to start at the snap. *A forward pass is ruled incomplete. *Either team calls for a [[time-out (sport)|timeout]] or an official calls for a timeout, perhaps because a player is injured or there is a penalty on the play. Officials will restart the clock after an official timeout, but not a team timeout, has concluded unless another of the conditions applies, or if the timeout is for a penalty enforcement after the 2-minute warning of the first half or inside the last 5 minutes of the second half/overtime (absent special timing rules for specific fouls). **10 seconds will be taken off the clock, and the clock started when the ball is spotted, if the offense, after the 2-minute warning of either half, fouls or commits certain other acts that cause the clock to stop (including an injury when the offense is out of timeouts, except under certain circumstances), unless the clock will stop anyway for a different reason. In Canadian football, the offense may execute one additional [[untimed play]] if the clock expires while the ball is not in play.
*A score or touchback occurs. Additionally, the clock does not run during or after a [[Conversion (gridiron football)|conversion attempt]] in the NFL or NCAA college football. *Possession of the football is transferred between teams for any reason. *In [[college football]], the clock is briefly stopped when a team earns a [[down (football)|first down]] to allow the [[chain crew]] to reposition themselves. The [[NFL]] has no such stoppage.
If the clock runs out during a play, the current play is allowed to continue to its conclusion. If the clock runs out between downs, the period ends in American football, but in Canadian football the offense is allowed one last down.
Each team is given three timeouts per half which they can use to stop the clock from running after a play. In the NFL, teams get two timeouts in a preseason or regular season overtime period, or three in a postseason overtime half.
On a fair-catch punt, the clock starts at the snap and stops at the end of the play.
===Strategies=== {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2017}}
==== Strategies for leading teams on offense ==== A team on offense that has the higher score seeks to use as much time as possible. A drive that scores no points may nevertheless benefit the team by taking time off the clock. The team may:
*Favor run plays over pass plays. *Use the center of the field rather than the sidelines to avoid going out of bounds and stopping the clock. *Delay the start of each play until the [[play clock]] approaches 0.
The team may use counterintuitive game plans, such as declining to score or allowing the opponents to score, to accelerate the end of the game.
If the defense does not have enough time-outs to stop the clock before the ball is [[turnover on downs|turned over on downs]], the offense can [[running out the clock|run out the clock]] by executing repeated [[quarterback kneel]]s until the clock runs out. In the NFL and college football, up to 40 seconds can be taken off the clock between plays. The NFL also has a built-in [[two-minute warning]] that stops the clock after the play that occurs when the clock hits two minutes ends. In order to successfully run out the clock by kneeling, there must be less than 40 seconds on the clock if the opponent has two time-outs, 1 minute 20 seconds if the opponent has one time-out, or 2 minutes if the defense has no time-outs remaining, at the beginning of the series of downs. The offense can burn further time off the clock by [[timewasting]]: keeping the ball live (and the clock running) simply by keeping away from any defensive player, regardless of position on the field.
==== Strategies for trailing teams on offense ==== A team on offense that has the lower score seeks to conserve time. The team may: *Use a [[no-huddle offense]]; forgo detailed design of a play and instead signal and initiate a play quickly. *Have the quarterback "spike" the ball, sacrificing a down to stop the clock. (An explicit exception is written into the American football rule books so that the move is not penalized for [[intentional grounding]].) *Use a passing play (because an [[incomplete pass]] stops the clock) or a run play toward the sidelines (because taking the ball out of bounds also stops the clock). ** Most ideal after a 1st down. *If a play ends such that the game clock continues running, use a [[Time-out (sport)#Gridiron football|timeout]]. *If the ball is still alive while the clock runs out and the team with the ball is still trailing, do everything within the team's power to keep the ball alive until it can be advanced to the end zone. Often this incorporates a series of [[lateral pass|lateral and backward passes]] to avoid the ball carrier being tackled and the game ending.
A team that is tied or trailing by one or two points but is within the [[red zone (gridiron football)|red zone]] (and thus in easy [[field goal range]]) seeks to burn a specific amount of time off the clock, such that they can stop the clock with five or fewer seconds on the clock, so that their [[placekicker]] can kick a [[field goal (gridiron football)|field goal]] [[buzzer beater|with no time remaining]] and win the game.
==== Strategies for the defense ==== A team on defense has little control over the pace of the game. It may expend its timeouts to ensure that there is adequate time left on the clock, in case the team regains possession. The defense can make decisions on how to stop the ball carrier based on whether the team is trailing or leading: if the offense is trying to conserve time, the defense can foil that by tackling the ball carrier in-bounds before they can get [[out of bounds]]. Defenses likewise can safely devote more personnel to the perimeter and leave the center of the field less defended, as an offense that cannot afford to keep the clock running will have to throw toward the sidelines. Various rules ensure that the defense cannot [[Hack-a-Shaq|deliberately commit fouls to manipulate the game clock]], and in the most extreme such cases, an [[unfair act]] can be declared and the game [[forfeit (sport)|forfeited]] to the offense. (Likewise, if the offense commits fouls to burn off time and get extra downs, the clock is reset and [[unsportsmanlike conduct]] is called on them.)
== Canadian football == In [[Canadian football]], a team trailing by one point or tied has an additional option: a ball can be kicked from anywhere on the field in that sport, and balls kicked into or through the end zone and not returned score a [[single (football)|single point]]. This allows a team trailing by one to advance the ball upfield, then punt the ball toward the end zone in hopes of tying the game for one point (the player could also [[drop kick]] the ball, which would allow the kicking team to win on a [[field goal]] if kicked through the uprights). To prevent this scenario, defending teams will place their [[punter (football)|punter]] in the end zone to retrieve the ball and kick it back out of the end zone, preventing that single point from being scored.
Several of the strategies discussed above for American football above can be used in the Canadian code, however [[Comparison of American and Canadian football|rule differences]] mean that running out the clock much more difficult:
*Teams are allowed only three downs to advance the ball 10 yards without losing possession (as opposed to four in the American game). *The offensive team has only 20 seconds after the ball is whistled into play to start a new play (as opposed to 25 seconds in American high school football and 40 seconds from the end of the last play in college football and the NFL). *After the [[three-minute warning]] in Canadian football, two key timing changes occur: **The clock stops after every play. The clock restarts when the referee whistles the ball in play after a tackle in bounds, and with the snap after an incomplete pass or a tackle out of bounds. **A "time count" (the same foul as "delay of game" in American football), which is a 5-yard penalty (with the down repeated) at other points in the game, becomes a loss of down penalty on first or second down and a 10-yard penalty on third down. Additionally, if the referee deems a time count violation on third down in the last three minutes of a half to be deliberate, he can require the offensive team to legally place the ball in play within the 20-second count, with a violation resulting in loss of possession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cflofficials.ca/docs/2015%20Rule%20Book%20English.pdf|title=Rule 1, Section 7, Article 9: Time Count|work=The Official Playing Rules for the Canadian Football League 2015|publisher=Canadian Football League|pages=18–19|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222133157/http://www.cflofficials.ca/docs/2015%20Rule%20Book%20English.pdf|archivedate=December 22, 2015|deadurl=yes|accessdate=December 21, 2015|df=}}</ref> *If the clock hits 0:00 between plays, Canadian teams are required to execute one final play, even if the ball has not yet been snapped. In the American game, if the clock hits 0:00 between plays, the game is over unless the previous play ended in a defensive penalty, a score, or circumstances warranting various types of kicks.
These differences make for radically different endgames if the team with the lead has the ball. In the NFL, a team can run 120 seconds (2 minutes)--and slightly more in the NCAA--off the clock without gaining a first down (assuming that the defensive team is out of timeouts). In the Canadian game, just over 40 seconds can be run off. ==See also==
*[[Gaming the system]] *[[Running out the clock]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{Cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espnmag/story?section=magazine&id=3837344 |title=3-2-1 ... Meltdown |publisher=''[[ESPN The Magazine]]'' |date=2009-01-16 |accessdate=2016-02-28}} * [http://www.johntreed.net/FCM.html A clock-management manual]
{{American football concepts}} {{American football strategy}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clock Management}} [[Category:American football strategy]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox bodybuilder |image=
| name = Erik Fankhouser | | image_size = 300px | caption = | nickname = "The House" | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|05|30}} | birth_place = | height = 5' 9" / 175.5 cm. | weight = Contest: 215lb Off season: 265lb | bestwin = | bestwinyear = | predecessor = | successor = }}
'''Erik Fankhouser''' (born May 30, 1980) is a professional American bodybuilder in the sport’s heavyweight class.
Fankhouser began weight training while he was a student at [[West Liberty State College]] in [[West Liberty, West Virginia]]. He originally focused on playing fullback for the school’s football team and participating in the shot put, discus, hammer and javelin events for the track team, and then turned his focus to bodybuilding. He won his first competitive bodybuilding tournament, the 2004 NPC Upper Ohio Valley, placing first in the junior division. He won the Mr. West Virginia title in the 2005 Mid Atlantic Grand Prix/West Virginia States.<ref name="westliberty.edu">[http://www.westliberty.edu/uploadedFiles/Faculty_and_Staff/College_Relations_and_Marketing/fall_07_online.pdf “Pro Bodybuilder is in the ‘House’ Top of the Hill Magazine]</ref>
In his first national competition, the 2006 North American Championship, he placed fourth in the heavyweight division. In 2007, he placed 16th in the USA Bodybuilding & Figure Championships, but in his next competition he placed first in his class in the North American Championships. He was also named overall winner for the competition and earned his [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] pro card at that event.<ref>[http://www.musculardevelopment.com/browse/index.php?mode=browse&id=10016 Muscular Development Magazine (Online Edition)]</ref> With his victory, Fankhouser made state sports history as the first West Virginia native to become a professional bodybuilder.<ref>[http://www.wtrf.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=32573 “Man Making "Big" Strides in Career” WTRF-TV]</ref> Erik placed 10th in his first IFBB pro contest, the Europa Super Show, in August 2008, winning both Pose Down Magazine's "Best Wheels" and the 4Ever Fit Fans' Choice awards during the contest.
Fankhouser, who stands 5’9” and averages 215 pounds in contest shape, goes by the nickname “The House.” He is sponsored in his training by the [[bodybuilding supplement]] companies Animalpak.com and Universal Nutrition.<ref>[http://www.bodybuilding.com/fun/weik63.htm Bodybuilding.com interview]</ref> He has also done guest posing at several bodybuilding tournaments, and writes weight training articles for ''Muscular Development Magazine.''<ref name="westliberty.edu"/>
Outside of competitive bodybuilding, he works as an [[exercise physiologist]] at Wheeling Hospital in [[Wheeling, West Virginia]].
== Contest History == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Contest !! Placing |- | 2006 || IFBB North American Championships || HeavyWeight, 4th |- | 2007 || NPC USA Championships HeavyWeight || DNP |- | 2007 || IFBB North American Championships || HeavyWeight & Overall, 1st |- | 2008 || IFBB 15th Annual Sports/Fitness Weekend & Europa IFBB Super Show || 11th |- | 2009 || IFBB Europa Supershow Open || 11th |- | 2010 || IFBB New York Pro || 5th |- | 2010 || IFBB Mr. Olympia || 18th |}
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{infobox baseball team | name = Fukuoka Red Warblers | established = 2007 | logo = | cap_logo = | league = [[Shikoku Island League]] (2008–2009) | former_leagues = | former_division = | uniform = | retirednumbers = | colors = Red, Dark Blue, White
{{color box|#FF0000}} {{color box|#334466}} {{color box|#FFFFFF}} | nicknames = | former_names = | ballpark = [[Fukuoka Prefecture]] | pastparks = | series = | series_champs = | division_champ_type = | division_champs = | owner = | manager = [[Ryoji Moriyama]] | gm = | current = }} The {{nihongo|'''Fukuoka Red Warblers'''|福岡レッドワーブラーズ}} were a [[baseball]] team in the [[Shikoku-Kyūshū Island League]] of [[Japan]]. The team was established as part of the expansion of the league (along with the [[Nagasaki Saints]]). They started league play during the {{by|2008}} season, lasting through the 2009 season. The team's home was [[Fukuoka Prefecture]]. Its name combined the color of the prefecture's symbol flower, the ''[[ume]]'', and the prefectural bird, the [[Japanese bush-warbler]]. ==External links== * [https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Fukuoka_Red_Warblers Baseball-Reference "Bullpen"] *[http://www.nikkansports.com/baseball/f-bb-tp0-20080121-310056.html Nikkan Sports article] {{ja icon}} *[http://www.nishinippon.co.jp/nsp/local/20080128/20080128_001.shtml Nishinippon article]{{dead link|date=April 2015}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080202071451/http://www.iblj.co.jp/warblers/company.html IBLJ page (not yet public as of February 5, 2008)] *[http://iblj.ds-lab.jp/html/pdf/newsrelease071225142101.pdf IBLJ press release]{{dead link|date=April 2015}} *[https://archive.is/20120214093121/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/e-japan/fukuoka/news/20080129-OYT8T00671.htm Yomiuri Shimbun article] {{Shikoku Island League}} [[Category:Baseball teams in Japan]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 2008]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Sports teams in Fukuoka Prefecture]] {{japan-baseball-team-stub}}

{{Infobox national sports federations |assocname= Hellenic Handball Federation
''{{lang-el|Ομοσπονδία Χειροσφαιρίσεως Ελλάδος}}'' |abbrev= OXE |logo= Hellenic Handball Federation logo.jpeg |logosize= 190px |countryflag= Greece |iocnation= [[Hellenic Republic]] (GRE) |url= www.Handball.org.gr |sport= [[Handball]] |othersport1= [[Beach Handball]] |othersport2= [[Wheelchair Handball]] |historytitle=HISTORY |precedingorganisationsname= |yearfounded= {{Start date and age|1979| | |df=y}} |formernames= |demographicstitle=DEMOGRAPHICS |noofclubs= |noofaffclubs= |membershipsize= |participationlevels= |affliationstitle=AFFLIATIONS |IF = [[International Handball Federation]] | IF_abbr = IHF | IF_joined = 1979 |nationalolympiccom= [[Hellenic Olympic Committee]] |continentalassoc= [[European Handball Federation]] |nocyearjoined= |otheraff2= [[Mediterranean Handball Confederation]] |otheraff3= |otheraff4= |electedtitle= GOVERNING BODY |patron= |president=[[Gkandis Konstantinos]] {{flagicon|GRE}} |sectitle= HEADQUARTERS |address1= [[Athens]] |country= [[Greece]] |chiefexec= |secretarygeneral= [[Stamatiadis Konstantinos]] {{flagicon|GRE}} |financetitle=FINANCE |companystatus= |operatingincome= |sponsors= }} The '''Hellenic Handball Federation''' (OXE) (''{{lang-el|Ομοσπονδία Χειροσφαιρίσεως Ελλάδος}}'') is the governing body of [[handball]] and [[beach handball]] in [[Hellenic Republic]] (Greece). Founded in 1979, OXE is affiliated to the [[International Handball Federation]] and [[European Handball Federation]]. OXE is also affiliated to the [[Hellenic Olympic Committee]] and the [[Mediterranean Handball Confederation]]. It is based in [[Athens]].{{cite web|url=http://ihf.info/TheIHF/ContinentalFederations/EuropeanHandballFederation(EHF)/ListofFederations/HellenicHandballFederation.aspx|title=Profile at IHF website|date=17 November 2017|work=ihf.info}} ==OXE Competitions== * [[Greek Men's Handball Championship]] * [[Greek Women's Handball Championship]] * [[Greek Men's Handball Cup]] * [[Greek Women's Handball Cup]] * [[A2 Ethniki Handball]] ==National teams== * [[Greece national handball team]] * [[Greece national junior handball team]] * [[Greece national youth handball team]] * [[Greece women's national handball team]] * [[Greece women's junior national handball team]] * [[Greece women's youth national handball team]] ==Competitions hosted== ===International=== * [[1991 Men's Junior World Handball Championship]] * [[Handball at the 2004 Summer Olympics| 2004 Summer Olympics]] * [[2011 Men's Junior World Handball Championship]] * [[2021 Men's Youth World Handball Championship]] (Future event) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.Handball.org.gr/ Official website] (Only Greek Language) * [http://ihf.info/TheIHF/ContinentalFederations/EuropeanHandballFederation(EHF)/ListofFederations/HellenicHandballFederation.aspx Hellenic Handball Federation] at IHF site [[Category:European Handball Federation|Members]] [[Category: 1979 establishments in Greece]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Greece|Handball]] [[Category: Sports organisations established in 1979]] [[Category: Handball governing bodies]] {{Handball in Greece}} {{Sports governing bodies in Greece}} {{National members of the European Handball Federation}} {{National Members of the International Handball Federation}} {{sport-org-stub}} {{Handball-stub}} {{Greece-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox Hollywood cartoon | cartoon_name = Hockey Homicide | series = [[Goofy]] | image = Hockey_homicide.jpg | caption = | director = [[Jack Kinney]] | musician = [[Paul Smith (film and television composer)|Paul Smith]] | animator = [[Jack Boyd]]
John Sibley
Hal King
[[Milt Kahl]]
[[Al Bertino]] (uncredited)
[[Cliff Nordberg]] (uncredited)
[[Les Clark]] (uncredited)
[[Ward Kimball]] (uncredited)
[[Andy Engman]] (uncredited){{cite web|url=http://cartoonresearch.com/index.php/disneys-hockey-homicide-1945/|title=Disney’s “Hockey Homicide” (1945)|publisher=|accessdate=27 May 2016}} | story_artist = Bill Berg
[[Dick Kinney]] | voice_actor = [[Pinto Colvig]] (uncredited)
[[Doodles Weaver]] (uncredited) | original music = [[Paul Smith (composer)|Paul J. Smith]] | layout_artist = Don da Gradi | background_artist = Art Riley | producer = [[Walt Disney]] | studio = [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Productions]] | distributor = [[RKO Pictures|RKO Radio Pictures]] | release_date = September 21, 1945 (USA) | color_process = [[Technicolor]] | runtime = 7 min (one reel) | preceded_by = ''Californy'er Bust'' (1945) | followed_by = ''A Knight for a Day'' (1946) | movie_language = [[English language|English]] }} '''''Hockey Homicide''''' is a [[cartoon]] made by [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Productions]] in 1945. ==Synopsis== Narrator [[Doodles Weaver]] explains the rules of [[ice hockey]] in satirical format. The narration's emphasis on good sportsmanship is countered by the violence of the players (all of them "played" by [[Goofy]]). Team captains Ice Box Bertino and Fearless Ferguson are rivals who brutally fight each other and incur a penalty before the game can begin, sending both of them to the penalty box; subsequently, they are constantly released from the box only to be sent back to it as they cannot help but fight each other on the ice. Eventually, confusion over many extra hockey pucks leads the players and spectators to get into a massive brawl, during which snippets from other Disney cartoons (including ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'', ''[[How to Play Football]]'', ''[[How to Play Baseball]]'', and ''[[Victory Through Air Power (film)|Victory Through Air Power]]'') are included to emphasize the mass confusion. Meanwhile, the Loose Leafs' and the Ant Eaters' team members excitedly and intently watch the action from high in the stands while enjoying themselves, with the closing narration implying that they irritate each other's fans into fighting so the players themselves can watch instead. ==Production notes== * The names of all the players are named after various members of the Disney staff. The list below is from the scorecard early in the short. {| class="wikitable" |- ! '''Referee''' !! '''Scorer''' |- | [[Jack Kinney|Clean Game Kinney]] || [[Myron Nelson]] |- |colspan="2"| |- ! '''Loose Leafs Roster/Moose''' !! '''Ant Eaters Roster/Pelicans''' |- | [[Charles August Nichols|Kewpie Nichols]] || [[Al Zinnen|Zip Zinnen]] |- | [[Jack Hannah|Slugger Hannah]] || [[Hal Adelquist|Tiger Adelquist]] |- | [[Eric Larson|Swede Larson]] || [[Ted Sebern|Bullet Sebern]] |- | [[Lance Nolley|Catfish Nolley]] || [[Dick Shaw|Lightning Shaw]] |- | [[Al Bertino|Ice Box Bertino]] || [[Norm Ferguson (animator)|Fearless Ferguson]] |- | [[Roy Williams (artist)|Moose Williams]] || [[Karl Karpe|Wildcat Karpe]] |- | [[Milt Kahl|Killer Kahl]] || [[Iron Pants Dunham]] |- | [[Paul Smith (composer)|Hurricane Smith]] || [[Hal King (animator)|Butch King]] |- | [[John Sibley (animator)|Terror Sibley]] || [[Cliff Nordberg|Bomber Nordberg]] |- | [[Jack Boyd]] || [[Bill Peet|Speed Peed]] |- | [[Art Riley|Spike Riley]] || [[Russ Dyson|Dippy Dyson]] |} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0037784|Hockey Homicide}} [[Category:1945 films]] [[Category:1945 animated films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:Disney animated short films, 1940s]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Goofy (Disney) short films]] [[Category:Ice hockey films]] [[Category:Sports animation]] [[Category:Films directed by Jack Kinney]] [[Category:Films produced by Walt Disney]] [[Category:Films scored by Paul Smith (film and television composer)]] [[Category:Sports comedy films]] {{Disney-animation-film-stub}}

page.title: Islamic Republic of Iran Baseball and Softball Association

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
[[File:Baseball_and_softball_iran.jpg|right]] [[File:Iran National Team.JPG|Iran National Team In Pakistan|thumb|350px|right]] The '''Baseball and Softball Association of the Islamic Republic of Iran''' ({{lang-fa|انجمن بیس بال و سافت بال جمهوری اسلامی ایران}}) is the governing body for [[baseball]] and [[softball]] in [[Iran]]. It was founded in 1993 as a baseball, softball, [[cricket (sport)|cricket]] and [[rugby union]] federation, but split from [[Rugby and Cricket Federation of the Islamic Republic of Iran|the rugby and cricket federation]] in 2010.
There are 11 provincial teams that compete in two annual national championships. The first national championship is in August and the second in February. Tehran has won 9 out of the 12 championships while Kerman, Isfahan, and Booshehr have each finished first once.
== Previous presidents ==
[[Baseball]], [[softball]], [[cricket]] and [[rugby union]] federation era:
* [[Bahram Afsharzadeh]] (1993–2001) * [[Mohamamd Bagher Zolfagharian]] (2001–2004) * [[Abdollah Ramezanzadeh]] (2004–2006) * [[Hossein Sadegh-Abedin]] (2006–2010)
[[Baseball]] and [[softball]] association era:
* [[Hamid Reza Asemi]] (2010–2013) * [[Alireza Adib]] (2013-present)
==See also== *[[Iran national baseball team]] *[[Iran Championship]] ==External links== * {{fa icon}} [http://www.ibasa.ir/ Official website]
{{Sports governing bodies in Iran}}
[[Category:Sports governing bodies in Iran|Baseball federation]] [[Category:Baseball in Iran|Federation]] [[Category:Baseball governing bodies in Asia|Ir]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1993]] {{Iran-sport-stub}} {{asia-baseball-stub}}

{{about|the sculpted fountains||Kugel (disambiguation)}} [[File:Kugelball.svg|thumb|Principle of operation of a Kugel fountain
(A) Water flowing between the sphere and its shaped holder lifts the ball slightly.
(B) Water flows over the holder's sides into a reservoir.
(C) Water is pumped back in an endless loop.
(D) Pump.
(E) Ball can easily be moved by hand.]] A '''kugel fountain''' (also called a '''"floating" sphere fountain''' or by the [[pleonasm|pleonasmic]] name '''kugel ball''') is a [[water feature]] or sculpture where a [[sphere]] sits in a [[ball joint|fitted hollow]] in a pedestal, and is supported by [[aquaplaning]] on a thin film of water. Pressurized water flows between the sphere and socket, creating a mechanical [[fluid bearing]] that is nearly frictionless. The sphere can weigh thousands of [[pound (mass)|pound]]s, but the efficient bearing allows it to be spun by the force of a hand.{{cite journal|title=Physics of the granite sphere fountain|work=American Journal of Physics|first1=Jacco H.|last1=Snoeijer|first2=Ko|last2=van der Weele|volume=82|issue=11|pages=1029–39|date=November 2014|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aapt/journal/ajp/82/11/10.1119/1.4886365|doi=10.1119/1.4886365}} The sphere does not float, being [[density|denser]] than water; it is often made from [[granite]].{{cite journal |last1=Snoeijer |first1=Jacco H. |last2=der Weele |first2=Ko van |title=Physics of the granite sphere fountain |journal=American Journal of Physics |date=November 2014 |volume=82 |issue=11 |pages=1029–1039 |doi=10.1119/1.4886365 |url=http://stilton.tnw.utwente.nl/people/snoeijer/Papers/2014/SnoeijerAJP14.pdf}} The hydraulics of the fountain can be controlled so that the [[axis of rotation]] of the sphere changes continually.{{cite web |title=Floating Sphere (Kugel ball fountain) from the market leader {{!}} KusserUSA |url=http://www.kusserusa.com/floating-spheres-rings-discs-wheels.html |website=www.kusserusa.com |language=en}} Ring sculptures that rotate on an [[Axis of rotation|axis]] are also built.{{cite web |url= http://floatingspherefountain.com/stone-ring-fountain |title= Ring water feature |work= Brahma Granitech, India |accessdate= 21 May 2015}} Kugel fountains can be found all over the world. Many are at popular tourist destinations, such as science museumsAmanda Oaks, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926213334/http://www.richmond.com/museums/output.aspx?Article_ID=3195201&Vertical_ID=155&tier=20&position=6 Richmond in the Record Books], Richmond.com, 18 August, [2004], Retrieved on 18 September 2007 shopping centers, lobbies, and gardens. The term ''kugel'' is from the German word ''Kugel'' for ''[[ball]]'' or ''[[sphere]]''.{{cite web |url= http://dictionary.reverso.net/german-english/Kugel |title= German-English dictionary: Kugel translation |work= Reverso.net |accessdate = 21 May 2015}} ==Kugel fountains== File:Reaching for the Stars.jpg|[[Celestial globe]], weighing nine tons, being spun by a child. File:Kugel Ball in Lansdale.jpg|[[Lansdale (SEPTA station)|Lansdale station]], Railroad Plaza, [[Lansdale, Pennsylvania]] File:Malta - Sliema - Triq It-Torri - floating sphere fountain 01 ies.ogv|[[Sliema]], [[Malta]] File:Bottrop - Kirchplatz - Kugelbrunnen 02 (0) ies.ogv|The Kirchplatz fountain in [[Bottrop]], [[Germany]], with pigeon File:Wuppertal Willy-Brandt-Platz 2014 016.webm|The transplanted Döppersberger Brunnenhttps://www.denkmal-wuppertal.de/2014/01/neuer-doppersberger-brunnen-1989.html in its new location in the [[Willy Brandt|Willy-Brandt]]-Platz in [[Wuppertal]], [[Germany]] ==Locations of kugel fountains== {{GeoGroupTemplate}} {{Expand list|date=February 2011}} {{clear}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !|Facility!!City!!Country!!Diameter!!class="unsortable"|GPS Coordinate!!class="unsortable"|Further information |- |Casino Innsbruck |[[Innsbruck]] |Austria |ball-Ø 120 cm, base: 6 x Ø 1.9 m x 12 cm |{{coord|47.262688|N|11.396148|E|scale:1000}} |This kugelbrunnen (English: kugel fountain) is located in front of the Casino Innsbruck at Salurner Straße 15 in Innsbruck, Austria. page.title: List of historical NBA over-the-air television broadcasters

revision.text:
[[Television broadcasting]] started around the 1950s and has continued to grow and become more sophisticated. When the [[National Basketball Association]] broadcasts first aired, they were broken down into four categories including; pre game, halftime, post game, and game coverage. Pregame casting usually covered a summary of predictions, key factors, and injuries. Halftime covered what happened in the first half, and the post game covered the game as a whole and the outcome. The game broadcast was a live game announcing that gave a play by play.{{cite journal|last=Sarmento|first=Mario R.|title=The NBA on Network Television: A Historical Analysis|date=December 1998|pages=6–8|citeseerx = 10.1.1.26.1281 }} ==Local== {| class="wikitable" |'''Team''' |'''Stations''' |'''Years''' |- |[[Atlanta Hawks]] |[[WXIA-TV|WQXI]]
