{{About|the trademark-protected 3M product|the product category|all-weather running track}} [[File:Athletics track.jpg|thumb|right|Starting places on tartan track]] '''Tartan Track''' is a [[trademarked]] all-weather synthetic track surfacing made of [[polyurethane]] used for [[track and field]] competitions, manufactured by [[3M]]. It lets athletes compete in bad weather without serious performance loss and improves their results over other surfaces. It also provides a more consistent surface for competition even under optimum weather. Such tracks have become the standard for most elite competitions.
Because the "Tartan" brand name was the first and was widely successful in its time, the name Tartan has been incorrectly{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} used as a [[genericized trademark]] for description of an [[all-weather running track]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.athleticsireland.ie/content/?p=5970 |title=example 1 of misused term |publisher=Athleticsireland.ie |date=2009-03-25 |accessdate=2014-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201204318/http://www.athleticsireland.ie/content/?p=5970 |archivedate=2014-02-01 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coloribus.com/adsarchive/prints/pritt-correct-it-refill-roller-tartan-track-9501805/ |title=example 2 of misused term |publisher=Coloribus.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref>
3M's first generation [[artificial turf]] of the late 1960s and early 1970s was branded as "Tartan Turf."<ref name=trnost>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KB4cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O1EEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7477%2C5041055 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Press |last=Spatter |first=Sam |title='Three Rivers' name of stadium |date=February 12, 1969 |page=66 }}</ref>
== History == The [[1968 Summer Olympics]] at [[Mexico City]] was the first [[Olympic Games]] to use the Tartan track surface in athletics.<ref>{{cite web|author=William Oscar Johnson |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1119745/index.htm |title=Sports Illustrated August 12, 1985 |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=1985-08-12 |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref> [[Athletics at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's shot put|Olympic shot put champion]] [[Bill Nieder]] was instrumental in developing the product and selling it for use in the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elitetrack.com/blogs-details-2764/ |title=Bill Nieder: Putter Formulated The Rubber Room |publisher=Elitetrack |date= |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref>
American track and field coach [[Bert Bonanno]], who had been recruited by the Mexican Olympic Committee to help prepare their athletes, worked as a liaison between the Mexican officials and manufacturer 3M in 1968.<ref name="air">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8NCXcrGcjiwC&pg=PA110&lpg=PA110 |title=Something in the Air: American Passion and Defiance in the 1968 Mexico City Olympics |publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press|Bison Books]] |author=Richard Hoffer |year=2009 |pages=110–113 |accessdate=March 5, 2015|isbn=978-0-8032-3629-5}}</ref> “It had been red cinder at the Olympic Games up until then. 3M hired [[Jesse Owens]] to assist them to convince the Mexican Olympic Committee to put that track in,” Bonanno said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://speedendurance.com/2011/03/02/bud-winter-biography-san-jose-state-university-1940-1970-part-1/ |title=Bud Winter Biography, San Jose State University 1940-1970, Part 1|publisher=SpeedEndurance.com |accessdate=March 5, 2015 }}</ref>
A Tartan track was constructed for the men's [[United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|U.S. Olympic Trials]] at [[Echo Summit]], [[California]], west of [[South Lake Tahoe, California|South Lake Tahoe]]. Just off [[U.S. Route 50 in California|U.S. Route 50]], it was built in the summer of 1968 in the parking lot of Nebelhorn ski area, at an [[elevation]] of {{convert|7377|ft}}.<ref name=olcpb>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rztWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dekDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7207%2C298421 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Olympic camp's press 'ban' unpopular |last=Payne |first=Bob |date=August 16, 1968 |page=18 }}</ref>
The original trade name "Tartan" came from 3M, manufacturers of [[Scotch Tape]] and continuing the Scotch name tradition. Those original tracks required [[mercury (element)|mercury]] as a catalyst, later found to be an environmental hazard. An independent company has perfected the process without mercury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tartan-aps.com/checking_for_mercury.php |title=Tartan Tracks Mercury test |publisher=Tartan-aps.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref> There are now numerous competitors in the "all-weather track" industry. In fact, the "Tartan" tracks of the late 1960s were the second generation of all-weather track surfacing. Before that, there were several tracks constructed of rubber (usually [[Tire recycling|tire shavings]]) and asphalt. The first recorded use of a Tartan Track surface in competition in England was a [[long jump]] at the Norman Green Sports Centre in [[Solihull]], September 16, 1967,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.runtrackdir.com/details.asp?track=solihull |title=Norman Green Athletics Centre |publisher=Runtrackdir.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref> though there were earlier uses in the United States.
==See also== *[[Playing field]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.tartan-aps.com Tartantrack.com] * [http://www.trackinfo.org/tracks.html trackinfo.org] location of all-weather tracks in the Western United States * [http://www.runtrackdir.com/ runtrackdir.com] location of all-weather tracks in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{Infobox film |name=The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg |image=The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg.jpg |caption=DVD cover |released={{film date|1998}} |country=United States |starring= |language = English |director=[[Aviva Kempner]] |producer=Aviva Kempner |writer=Aviva Kempner }} [[File:Hank Greenberg 1937 cropped.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Hank Greenberg]], Hall of Famer and 2-time MVP.]] '''''The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg''''' is a 1998 [[documentary film]] written, directed, and produced by [[Aviva Kempner]] about [[Hank Greenberg]], first baseman of the [[Detroit Tigers]], who was inducted into the [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]. A Jewish player who chose not to play on [[Yom Kippur]] in 1934 during a heated pennant race, Greenberg had to face a great deal of [[antisemitism]]. In 1938 he nearly broke [[Babe Ruth]]'s 60 home run record by hitting 58 home runs.
Like many players of the era, Greenberg had his career interrupted by military service during World War II. Initially, Greenberg was classified as unfit for service due to flat feet. However, upon re-examination, he was cleared. Before Japan's [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], the [[United States Congress]] had released men over age 28. After the attack, Greenberg immediately reenlisted in the [[United States Army Air Forces]].
In 1947, Greenberg, as a member of the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] and playing his final season, was one of the few ballplayers to give a warm welcome to [[Brooklyn Dodgers]]' [[Jackie Robinson]], the majors' first [[African-American|black]] player in many years. Robinson later said, "Class tells. It sticks out all over Mr. Greenberg".{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
== Production == Kempner states that the film took 13 years to make. "It was all about raising money for the rights to the archival and feature footage. That was so expensive that I had to stop and start about 20 times."<ref>http://www.insightnews.com/aesthetics/10810-aviva-kempner-qthe-life-and-times-of-hank-greenbergq</ref>
